## Tim Bailey's Political Funeral (1993){.smaller} :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > ACT UP showed that political silence and inaction were hostile, not neutral acts. The group collectively made the ill and dying's struggle to reverse the conditions that made AIDS a social and political crisis, visible and audible. :::{.fragment} > The Marys extended this work of support for the ill and dying, taking on the condition of death, which had previously conceptualized as activism's limit. They made the dead PWA body matter, and through the formation of political affinity, infused the corpse with the power to speak. (From Levine, 2020: ["How to do things with dead bodies"](https://hemisphericinstitute.org/en/emisferica-61/6-1-essays/how-to-do-things-with-dead-bodies.html)) ::: ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![Tim Bailey's Political Funeral (1993)](../images/20221121102149.png) ::: ::: ## ACT UP activists have maintained influence

## In small groups - How did the HIV activism of the late 1980s/early 1990s confront socioeconomic and racial inequity? What were the gaps? - How did listening to these episodes change how you think about clinical trials - from both a scientific and social perspective? - Are there echoes of John Snow's explorations in the drug development process? Why or why not? - What lessons from ACT UP and other HIV/AIDS activists do you think translate well to the present day?
